1.2: goog.testing.TestCase.Error.html
A class representing an error thrown by the test
goog.testing.TestCase.Result.html
A class for representing test results.
goog.testing.TestCase.Test.html
A class representing a single test function.
The order to run the auto-discovered tests.

A class representing a JsUnit test case. A TestCase is made up of a number of test functions which can be run. Individual test cases can override the following functions to set up their test environment:

  • runTests - completely override the test's runner
  • setUpPage - called before any of the test functions are run
  • tearDownPage - called after all tests are finished
  • setUp - called before each of the test functions
  • tearDown - called after each of the test functions
  • shouldRunTests - called before a test run, all tests are skipped if it returns false. Can be used to disable tests on browsers where they aren't expected to pass.

TestCase objects are usually constructed by inspecting the global environment to discover functions that begin with the prefix test. (See #autoDiscoverLifecycle and #autoDiscoverTests.)

Testing asychronous code with promises

In the simplest cases, the behavior that the developer wants to test is synchronous, and the test functions exercising the behavior execute synchronously. But TestCase can also be used to exercise asynchronous code through the use of promises. If a test function returns an object that has a then method defined on it, the test framework switches to an asynchronous execution strategy: the next test function will not begin execution until the returned promise is resolved or rejected. Instead of writing test assertions at the top level inside a test function, the test author chains them on the end of the returned promise. For example: 

   function testPromiseBasedAPI() {
     return promiseBasedAPI().then(function(value) {
       // Will run when the promise resolves, and before the next
       // test function begins execution.
       assertEquals('foo', value.bar);
     });
   }

Synchronous and asynchronous tests can be mixed in the same TestCase. Test functions that return an object with a then method are executed asynchronously, and all other test functions are executed synchronously. While this is convenient for test authors (since it doesn't require any explicit configuration for asynchronous tests), it can lead to confusion if the test author forgets to return the promise from the test function. For example: 

   function testPromiseBasedAPI() {
     // This test should never succeed.
     promiseBasedAPI().then(fail, fail);
     // Oops! The promise isn't returned to the framework,
     // so this test actually does succeed.
   }

Since the test framework knows nothing about the promise created in the test function, it will run the function synchronously, record a success, and proceed immediately to the next test function.

Promises returned from test functions can time out. If a returned promise is not resolved or rejected within promiseTimeout milliseconds, the test framework rejects the promise without a timeout error message. Test cases can configure the value of promiseTimeout by setting 

   goog.testing.TestCase.getActiveTestCase().promiseTimeout = ...
in their setUpPage methods.
Represents a test result.
currently active test case or null if not test is currently running. Tries the G_testRunner first then the stored value (when run outside of G_testRunner.

Gets list of objects that potentially contain test cases. For IE 8 and below, this is the global "this" (for properties set directly on the global this or window) and the RuntimeObject (for global variables and functions). For all other browsers, the array simply contains the global this.

An optional prefix. If specified, only get things under this prefix. Note that the prefix is only honored in IE, since it supports the RuntimeObject: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff521039%28VS.85%29.aspx TODO: Remove this option.
A list of objects that should be inspected.
Initializes the TestCase.
The test case to install.
Called when each test completes.
Initializes the given test case with the global test runner 'G_testRunner'.
The test case to install.
Called when each test completes.
Calls goog.testing.TestCase.prototype.invalidateAssertionException on the active test case if it is installed, and logs an error otherwise.
The exception object to invalidate.
Avoid a dependency on goog.userAgent and keep our own reference of whether the browser is IE.
TODO(user) replace this with prototype.currentTest. Name of the current test that is running, or null if none is running.

The maximum amount of time in milliseconds that the test case can take before it is forced to yield and reschedule. This prevents the test runner from blocking the browser and potentially hurting the test harness.

A class representing a JsUnit test case. A TestCase is made up of a number of test functions which can be run. Individual test cases can override the following functions to set up their test environment:

  • runTests - completely override the test's runner
  • setUpPage - called before any of the test functions are run
  • tearDownPage - called after all tests are finished
  • setUp - called before each of the test functions
  • tearDown - called after each of the test functions
  • shouldRunTests - called before a test run, all tests are skipped if it returns false. Can be used to disable tests on browsers where they aren't expected to pass.

TestCase objects are usually constructed by inspecting the global environment to discover functions that begin with the prefix test. (See #autoDiscoverLifecycle and #autoDiscoverTests.)

     return promiseBasedAPI().then(function(value) {
       // Will run when the promise resolves, and before the next
       // test function begins execution.
       assertEquals('foo', value.bar);
     });
   }

Test functions that return an object with a then method are executed asynchronously, and all other test functions are executed synchronously. While this is convenient for test authors (since it doesn't require any explicit configuration for asynchronous tests), it can lead to confusion if the test author forgets to return the promise from the test function.    function testPromiseBasedAPI() {
     // This test should never succeed.
     promiseBasedAPI().then(fail, fail);

     // so this test actually does succeed.
   }

Since the test framework knows nothing about the promise created in the test function, it will run the function synchronously, record a success, and proceed immediately to the next test function.

   goog.testing.TestCase.getActiveTestCase().promiseTimeout = ...
in their setUpPage methods.
The name of the test case, defaults to 'Untitled Test Case'.
Adds a new test to the test case.
The test to add.

Creates and adds a new test.

Convenience function to make syntax less awkward when not using automatic test discovery.
The test name.
Reference to the test function.
Optional scope that the test function should be called in.

Adds any functions defined on 'obj' (the global object, by default) that correspond to lifecycle events for the test case. Overrides setUp, tearDown, setUpPage, tearDownPage, runTests, and shouldRunTests if they are defined on 'obj'.
Defaults to goog.global.
Adds any functions defined in the global scope that are prefixed with "test" to the test case.
Clears a timeout created by this.timeout().
A timeout id.
Creates a goog.testing.TestCase.Test from an auto-discovered function.
The name of the function.
The auto-discovered function.
The newly created test.

Cycles through the tests, yielding asynchronously if the execution time exceeds #maxRunTime. In particular, there is no guarantee that the test case has finished execution once this method has returned. To be notified when the test case has finished execution, use #setCompletedCallback or #runTestsReturningPromise.
Handles a test that failed.
The test that failed.
The exception object associated with the failure or a string.
Handles a test that passed.
The test that passed.

Executes the tests, yielding asynchronously if execution time exceeds maxRunTime. There is no guarantee that the test case has finished once this method has returned. To be notified when the test case has finished, use #setCompletedCallback or #runTestsReturningPromise.
Finalizes the test case, called when the tests have finished executing.
Returns the number of tests actually run in the test case, i.e. subtracting any which are skipped.
The number of un-ignored tests.
The function name prefix used to auto-discover tests.
Time since the last batch of tests was started.
Returns the number of tests contained in the test case.
The number of tests.

Gets list of objects that potentially contain test cases. For IE 8 and below, this is the global "this" (for properties set directly on the global this or window) and the RuntimeObject (for global variables and functions). For all other browsers, the array simply contains the global this.

An optional prefix. If specified, only get things under this prefix. Note that the prefix is only honored in IE, since it supports the RuntimeObject: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff521039%28VS.85%29.aspx TODO: Remove this option.
A list of objects that should be inspected.
The name of the test.
Returns the number of script files that were loaded in order to run the test.
The number of script files.
Returns a string detailing the results from the test.
If true results will include data about all tests, not just what failed.
The results from the test.
Returns the test results.
Returns the amount of time it took for the test to run.
The run time, in milliseconds.
Returns the test results object: a map from test names to a list of test failures (if any exist).
Test results object.
Returns the test results as json. This is called by the testing infrastructure through G_testrunner.
Tests results object.
Gets the tests.
The test array.
Removes the specified exception from being tracked. This only needs to be called for internal functions that intentionally catch an exception, such as #assertThrowsJsUnitException.
The exception object to invalidate.
Whether the test case is running inside the multi test runner.
Whether the test was a success.
Logs an object to the console, if available.
The value to log. Will be ToString'd.
Failed test name.
The exception object associated with the failure or a string.
Error object.

Checks to see if the test should be marked as failed before it is run.

If there was an error in setUpPage, we treat that as a failure for all tests and mark them all as having failed.
The current test case.
Whether the test was marked as failed.
Returns the current test and increments the pointer.
The current test case.
The current time in milliseconds, don't use goog.now as some tests override it.

Makes note of an exception arising from an assertion, and then throws it. If the test otherwise passes (i.e., because something else caught the exception on its way to the test framework), it will be forced to fail.
The exception object being thrown.
Resets the test case pointer, so that next returns the first test.

Executes each of the tests, yielding asynchronously if execution time exceeds #maxRunTime. There is no guarantee that the test case has finished execution once this method has returned. To be notified when the test case has finished execution, use #setCompletedCallback or #runTestsReturningPromise.

Overridable by the individual test case. This allows test cases to defer when the test is actually started. If overridden, finalize must be called by the test to indicate it has finished.
Executes each of the tests, returning a promise that resolves with the test results once they are done running.
Saves a message to the result set.
The message to save.
Time since the last batch of tests was started.
Sets the callback function that should be executed when the tests have completed.
The callback function.
The sort order for running tests.
An object from which to extract test and lifecycle methods.
Sets the tests.
A new test array.
Set of tests to run. Entries in the set may be test names, like "testFoo", or numeric indicies. Only tests identified by name or by index will be executed.
Gets called before every goog.testing.TestCase.Test is been executed. Can be overridden to add set up functionality to each test.
Gets called before any tests are executed. Can be overridden to set up the environment for the whole test case.

Can be overridden in test classes to indicate whether the tests in a case should be run in that particular situation. For example, this could be used to stop tests running in a particular browser, where browser support for the class under test was absent.
Whether any of the tests in the case should be run.
Gets called after every goog.testing.TestCase.Test has been executed. Can be overriden to add tear down functionality to each test.
Gets called after all tests have been executed. Can be overridden to tear down the entire test case.
Calls a function after a delay, using the protected timeout.
The function to call.
Delay in milliseconds.
The timeout id.
Exception object that was detected before a test runs.
Whether the test should fail if exceptions arising from an assert statement never bubbled up to the testing framework.
The order to run the auto-discovered tests in.
The maximum time in milliseconds a promise returned from a test function may remain pending before the test fails due to timeout.
Object used to encapsulate the test results.
Whether the test case is running.
Whether the test case has ever tried to execute.
